nodes.text: Ensure pesticide use is consistent with product labels
Use IPM (Integrated Pest Management) approach
Perform daily pest management
Comply with federal and state regulations
Maintain short grass and trim shrubs
Pave access
Ensure proper drainage
Create 18-24 inch gravel strip around foundation
Place night-lights 30 feet away from doors
Keep framing at least 4 inches from walls
Fill necessary voids with materials like polyurethane foam
Coat concrete floors for improved sanitation.
Use acid-proof or brick floors for wet processing areas.
Pave dusty roads and maintain lawns.
Ensure proper drainage.
Position lighting away from buildings.
Reduce bird harborage.
Reduce outside food spillage.
Use rodent, insect, and bird traps.
Maintain housekeeping.
Implement pest monitoring programs.
Maintain bait stations.
Use insecticidal baits and approved insecticides.
Use chemical repellents and avicides.
Rodent-proof all openings.
Screen windows
Eliminate cracks, crevices, and ledges
Block bird access to ledges
Locate equipment off the floor or sealed to it
Keep all areas free of loose materials
Clean structures and equipment frequently
Use electrified grids inside for insect attraction
Inspect all incoming vehicles and materials
Store materials away from walls
Use rodent traps near doors
Map rodent trap locations
Use air curtains at doors
Use deterrents for birds on roosting sites
Use rodent bait stations where policy permits
Implement a detailed monitoring program and a total facility IPM program in Processing Area.
Use rodent traps near doors if needed in Processing Area.
Ensure proper sanitation in Processing Area.
Use space, spot, crack and crevice, and contact treatments as appropriate in Processing Area.
Implement a detailed monitoring program and a total facility IPM program in Packaging Areas.
Form an inspection committee with the highest company official as chairman and include all department heads.
Compile a list of deficiencies in categories: PC, OM, PP, M, C
Distribute notes to department heads for immediate action
Correct defects immediately
Review uncorrected items and assign realistic correction dates
Start by looking in obscure places using a flashlight to detect insect trails or mouse footprints in dust.
Observe suspect stock by spreading it on a flat surface and watching for movement.
Inspect areas most likely to produce results, such as under and inside equipment.
Suspect any unaccounted-for voids in equipment or structures.
Observe employee actions and in-plant practices.
Consider periodic inspections by an outside firm.
Require an 18-inch space between pallets and walls in the warehouse.
Create a written inspection procedure for incoming raw products.
Checks for products during raw product receiving.
Maintain records of problems.
Implement housekeeping standards.
Establish a pallet-cleaning program.
Set up stock storage specifications.
Use a reliable stock rotation method.
Determine economic threshold for control measures.
Monitor moisture content in postharvest systems.
Regulate temperature in postharvest systems.
Control pest access in postharvest systems.
Maintain appropriate time in postharvest systems.
Maintain suitable temperature (between 65°F and 95°F)
Perform visual inspection
Determine trap placement based on time of year and temperature profiles.
Inspect bagged commodities.
Identify pests.
Determine the extent of a problem.
Evaluate a treatment method.
Match the trap type to the environment.
Perform structural modifications
Implement non-chemical control
Apply chemical control to bulk seed storage
Carry out chemical control in warehouses
Execute rodent control program
Implement bird control
Read the label of a pesticide container.
Identify the food areas.
Identify non-food areas.
Apply pesticides to food areas according to label instructions.
Apply pesticides to non-food areas according to label instructions.
Ensure general residual applications are made according to label instructions.
Apply insecticide to limited areas where insects are likely to occur but will not contact food or workers (Spot application)
Apply small amounts of insecticide into cracks, crevices, expansion joints, and voids (Crack and Crevice application)
Regulate pesticide applications nationally through FIFRA by the EPA
Regulate pesticide applications in Arkansas by the Arkansas State Plant Board
Enforce pesticide tolerances for food and feed by the FDA
Enforce pesticide tolerances for meat by the USDA
Conduct a survey of the facility before application.
Identify the life cycle of beetles and moths.
Understand the characteristics of beetle larvae.
Understand the characteristics of moth larvae.
Identify the characteristics of adult beetles.
Identify the characteristics of adult moths.
Identify signs of pest infestation such as cast skins, egg cases, or a musty odor.
Implement sanitation measures
Use crack and crevice or spot treatments with residual pesticides
Supplement control with dusts and contact sprays
Control starts with sanitation and removal of breeding sites.
Lower humidity for controlling Booklice, Silverfish, and Firebrats.
Implement sanitation measures for controlling Booklice.
Manage lighting to reduce attraction of Crickets.
Remove decaying vegetation and moisture sources near foundations.
Understand rat and mouse behavior by recognizing their senses, reactions, and agility.
Identify rat and mouse signs, such as droppings and runways.
Look for cleared paths outdoors or greasy runways indoors.
Identify rubmarks - dark, greasy marks from rodent's body.
Identify burrows - prefer earth banks or under concrete.
Identify tracks - can be seen in dust or tracking patches.
Identify urine - fluoresces under blacklight.
Implement rodent management strategies.
Sanitation and habitat modification.
Store products on pallets.
Keep products away from walls.
Use rodent-proof construction methods.
Seal openings larger than 1/4 inch for mice and 1/2 inch for rats.
Use rodent-resistant materials like hardware cloth, sheet metal, and concrete.
Pay attention to doors, windows, vents, drainpipes, foundations, and utility lines.
Place toxic dust (tracking powders) in runways.
Select a proper bait
Use anticoagulants (first-generation or second-generation)
Use single-dose non-anticoagulants (bromethalin, cholecalciferol, zinc phosphide)
Norway rats prefer meat and fish
Roof rats prefer fruits and nuts
Use cereal grains for baits
Offer unpoisoned bait for several days
Use tamper-proof bait stations
Place stations along walls and runways
Place stations every 10 feet for mice
Place stations every 20 feet for rats
Use compressed air sprayer for crack and crevice, spot, and general sprays.
Clean the equipment after each use.
Check gaskets and valves regularly.
Never leave pressurized equipment unattended.
Determine the nozzle type for desired spray pattern.
Maintain nozzles by keeping them clean and dry.
Use dusters for applying dusts into voids, cracks, and burrows.
Keep dusters clean and dry during maintenance.
Choose appropriate aerosol or fog for space treating equipment.
Turn off pilot lights before thermal fogging.
Wear respirators during thermal fogging as indicated on the label.
Use air-purifying respirators when working with thermal fogging.
Supply clean air from an external source or a tank.
Approve respirators for pesticides by MSHA and NIOSH.
Ensure a proper fit.
Perform daily negative and positive pressure checks.
Wash respirators regularly.
Using outdated pesticide information
Not following label instructions
Building not constructed to prevent pests
Daily pest management not performed
Record keeping not done
Federal or state regulations not complied with
Short grass and trimmed shrubs must be maintained
Night-lights should be placed at least 30 feet away from doors
Framing must be kept at least 4 inches from walls
Wet processing areas require acid-proof or brick floors.
Wall materials should be sealed and easy to clean.
Drainage system is properly functioning
Lighting installation is at least 3 meters away from buildings
Bait stations are placed near rodent activity
Insecticidal baits and approved insecticides are used only near breeding sites
Chemical repellents and avicides are used appropriately for bird control
All building openings are rodent-proofed
Windows must be screened.
Cracks, crevices, and ledges must be eliminated before blocking bird access.
Equipment must not be on the floor or unsealed.
All areas must be kept free of loose materials at all times.
Structures and equipment must be cleaned frequently.
Electrified grids can only be used indoors for insect attraction.
Materials must be stored away from walls for inspection access.
Rodent traps should be placed near doors.
Air curtains should be used at doors.
Deterrents for birds should be used on roosting sites.
Rodent bait stations can only be used where policy permits.
The monitoring programs in Processing and Packaging Areas must be implemented in detail.
Rodent traps should be used near doors in Processing Area only when necessary.
Proper sanitation must be ensured in Processing Area.
Space treatments with nonresiduals, crack and crevice treatments with residuals, spot treatments, and fumigation must be used appropriately in Processing Area.
Finished foods in Packaging Areas are exposed and packaging materials can be a source of pests.
The inspection committee must be formed before starting the in-plant sanitation program.
Committee members must wear identifiable uniforms during inspections
Thorough inspections must be conducted before distributing notes
Departments must correct defects within the assigned time frame
Defects must be recorded completely and specifically
Areas with evidence of insect activity or mouse presence should be inspected first.
Equipment and structures with unaccounted-for voids should be thoroughly inspected.
Employee actions and in-plant practices should be observed during regular working hours.
An outside firm must be considered periodically for inspections.
The warehouse requires an 18-inch space between pallets and walls for inspections and pest prevention.
A written inspection procedure for raw product receiving is mandatory.
Records of problems during raw product receiving must be maintained.
Housekeeping standards must be implemented.
A pallet-cleaning program must be established.
Stock storage specifications must be set up.
A reliable stock rotation method must be used.
Economic threshold for control measures is exceeded
Moisture content in postharvest systems exceeds pest's requirement
Temperature in postharvest systems is within acceptable range
Pest access in postharvest systems is restricted
Appropriate time has elapsed in postharvest systems
Postharvest systems maintain desired moisture content
Temperature is between 65°F and 95°F
Rapid temperature drops are avoided
Stored product pests have exponential growth
Good sanitation and temperature control slow pest growth
Minimize insect movement
Carefully inspect all incoming materials
Time of year and temperature profiles are suitable for trap placement.
One trap should be placed per 4,000-5,000 square feet.
The identification of pests is crucial for interpreting trapping results.
Long-lived insects are less attracted to pheromone traps than short-lived ones.
Match the trap type to the environment.
Use pitfall traps or traps that deflect dust in dusty areas.
Adapt trap placement to changing temperature gradients throughout the year.
Placing traps on the outer perimeter of a facility.
Start with a wide grid (e.g., one trap per 100,000 cubic feet).
If pests are detected, move traps or add more to the suspect area.
Visually search areas where the most insects were captured.
Look for increases in numbers from one period to the next when interpreting catches.
Pheromone traps must be placed according to the recommended distance from the source for effective detection.
The temperature in cold storage should be maintained below 50°F.
Routine fumigation and empty bin treatments should be carried out as needed.
ULD treatments should be based on pheromone trap thresholds.
Structural exclusion methods should be used in addition to rodenticides.
Netting, sticky repellents, and avicides should only be used when necessary to minimize impact on non-target species.
Pesticide application must only be in accordance with the label.
Food areas should be identified before applying pesticides.
Non-food areas should be identified before applying pesticides.
Pesticides should be applied to food areas according to label instructions.
Pesticides should be applied to non-food areas according to label instructions.
General residual applications should be made according to label instructions.
Environmental conditions, such as temperature and humidity, may affect pesticide application.
Application areas should not exceed two square feet and should not contact food or workers.
Application in cracks, crevices, expansion joints, and voids is the only residual application permitted in food areas.
Pesticide regulations are enforced by the EPA and the Arkansas State Plant Board.
A pesticide used on a food product must have a tolerance or be exempt.
Survey of the facility should be conducted before application.
Facility's practices like cleaning and sanitation should be considered during the survey.
Presence of oval, black beetles or cockroaches
Detection of cast skins, egg cases, or musty odor
Sanitation measures must be implemented in areas preferred by cockroaches
Sanitation and removal of breeding sites must be performed before any other control measures.
Control operations must be carried out during appropriate weather conditions.
Humidity level is below a certain threshold
Sanitation measures are implemented
Lighting management is performed
The removal of decaying vegetation and moisture sources near foundations is a necessary condition for effective rodent control.
Understanding rat and mouse behavior is crucial before implementing control measures.
Presence of rubmarks indicates rodent activity.
Burrows should be located near earth banks or under concrete.
Effective rodent management requires identification of tracks.
Blacklight is necessary for identifying urine.
Sanitation and habitat modification must be implemented after rodent identification.
Openings larger than 1/4 inch for mice and 1/2 inch for rats must be sealed.
Use rodent-resistant materials during construction.
Attention should be paid to doors, windows, vents, drainpipes, foundations, and utility lines.
Products must not be stored directly against walls.
The compressed air sprayer must be used for crack and crevice, spot, and general sprays.
The equipment must be cleaned after each use.
Gaskets and valves must be checked regularly.
Pressurized equipment should not be left unattended.
Appropriate nozzle type must be determined for desired spray pattern.
Nozzles must be maintained by keeping them clean and dry.
Dusters must be kept clean and dry during maintenance.
Appropriate aerosol or fog must be chosen for space treating equipment.
Turn off pilot lights before thermal fogging.
Know cubic footage before thermal fogging.
Wear respirators during thermal fogging.
Use air-purifying respirators when working with thermal fogging.
The respirator used MUST be approved by MSHA and NIOSH.
Daily negative and positive pressure checks MUST be performed.
Clean air source SHOULD be available before starting the process.
